parts.title: The Evolution of Globalization through Seven Ages
parts.body: Globalization has been an essential aspect of human history, evolving through seven distinct ages. Each age showcases the interplay of geography, technology, and institutions. This journey began with humanity's migration in the Paleolithic Age, advancing to the agricultural growth of the Neolithic Age. The domestication of the horse marked the Equestrian Age, fostering long-distance trade. The Classical Age introduced large empires and trans-Eurasian interactions. The Ocean Age expanded territories across oceans, while the Industrial Age accelerated technological advancements. Today, the Digital Age challenges us with global interconnectedness through technology. The book emphasizes understanding these transitions to navigate future global changes wisely. This understanding is crucial now more than ever as we face contemporary challenges.

parts.title: Economic Transformation and Global Dynamics
parts.body: The chapter summarizes the progression of human societies from rural to urban living, highlighting changes in economic sectors and introducing geography, technology, and institutions as foundational elements of economies. Initial societal activities were primary sector-focused (agriculture and mining), but modern advances shifted employment towards services. Machines have largely replaced human physical labor, resulting in a service-dominant economy, especially in places like the United States, with 85% of jobs in services. The geographical, technological, and institutional factors are interdependent, influencing economic history as seen in inventions like the steam engine. Geographical factors include climate, disease patterns, and energy resources, all influencing a region's economic capabilities. Technology advances make natural resources more valuable, re-shaping geography's economic impact. Social institutions also play a crucial role, blending across geography and technology to influence society's functioning. Geopolitical considerations show how past empires leveraged technological advances in military and agriculture to expand. Yet rapid change, especially through means like digital technologies, continuously reshapes global power dynamics. The interconnectedness of these areas highlights how they collectively influence economic and societal development.

parts.title: The Significance of Horse Domestication in Eurasia
parts.body: Eurasia had long benefits of: scale, trade, innovation. Horse domestication (~5500 years ago) marked significant influence in Eurasia’s development. It facilitated transport, agriculture, military, and state governance, thus leading to the first Eurasian empires. The Eurasian steppes provided crucial grasslands for domestication. These steppe regions acted as highways for trade and exploration due to the ample energy input from the abundance of grass. Horse served as crucial transport comparable to modern vehicles.

parts.title: Impact of Domestication on Societies
parts.body: Animal domestication was crucial for economic and social progress. Domesticated species such as the donkey and horse profoundly impacted agriculture, trade, and communications. Regions without horses lagged behind economically and were often subject to conquest from cavalries. The domestication of horses began in Eurasia and spread to influence civilizations worldwide. Horses, known for their versatility and speed, dramatically changed the way societies evolved and interacted. Camelids also played significant roles in extreme climates. The dromedary and Bactrian camels of the Old World and the llama and alpaca of the New World were vital to trade and transport across difficult terrains like deserts and high plateaus. While camels were domesticated later than horses, they quickly became essential for trade routes and eventually complemented the warhorse in military campaigns. Camelids in the Andes enabled trade and agriculture between highlands and lowlands.

parts.title: Population and Empires in 100 CE
parts.body: The Han and Roman empires accounted for about half of the world's population by 100 CE, each having an estimated 60 million people. At this time, the Eurasian world was dominated by three major empires: Roman, Parthian, and Han. These empires were situated along the west-east axis through the lucky latitudes. Meanwhile, the Indian subcontinent was divided among various states like the Kushan and Indo-Greeks. Regions north and south also had distinct environments like the heavily forested northern Europe and the deserts of North Africa.

parts.title: Industrialization's Roots in Britain
parts.body: Britain's unique conditions made industrialization possible. An intellectual culture valuing science, evident in Newton's time at Cambridge, played a vital role. Successful deployment of Watt's steam engine also needed a supportive market system, strong patent laws, and private investors like Richard Boulton to fund innovations. Britain's coal industry gave it an advantage over competitors like Holland, lacking such resources. This resource fueled the steam engine, leading to further technological advancements. The steam engine was central to Britain's transition from an "organic" to an energy-rich economy as it powered multiple economic sectors. The steam engine's impact on textiles, metallurgy, and transport was vast and marked the rise of mechanization. It reduced costs across different sectors, including agriculture, enhancing global food production and population growth. The fossil fuel liberation enabled a significant rise in world population, as new agricultural methods increased food supply globally, freeing the economy from prior constraints of organic energy dependency.

parts.title: Technological Revolution and Connectivity
parts.body: The digital revolution is reshaping the world, with new patterns of global economic activity, jobs, and lifestyles. It poses ecological challenges due to human-induced climate change and biodiversity destruction. In the 21st century, trends like the rise of China and India, US decline, rapid African growth, and increased urbanization define global shifts. Our institutions are under strain from these changes, and as the biologist E.O. Wilson observed, we face "Stone Age emotions, medieval institutions, and godlike technology." The digital age, marked by ubiquitous connectivity, arises from advances such as 5G and will fundamentally alter globalization. The rapid uptake of digital techs is historically unprecedented, arising from foundational work like Alan Turing's envisioning of universal computers in 1936. John von Neumann's architecture for modern computers laid the foundations in 1945, leading to technological advances such as the invention of the transistor in 1947. This enabled the development of microprocessors and eventually the Internet, initially a military project, opened for public use in 1987. Moore's Law foresaw rapid growth; from 2,300 transistors in 1971 to 8 billion in 2017, underpinning the development of technologies that shape today's connectivity and digital intelligence.

parts.title: Convergent Growth and China's Surge
parts.body:
Convergent Growth and China’s Surge to the Forefront

The latter part of the 20th century marked a shift from global economic divergence towards global convergence. Following World War II, newly independent nations began to accelerate their growth, investing in public health, education, and infrastructure. Although some countries struggled with debt and inflation, many improved in these sectors, resulting in developing nations increasing their GDP per capita more swiftly than developed nations. This faster growth, alongside higher population growth, led to a rise in the share of global output from developing countries, which grew from 43% in 2000 to 59% in 2018, according to the IMF.

parts.title: UN Security Council Imbalance and Reform Proposal
parts.body: The table from 2018 highlights the imbalance in global representation, as countries like India, Japan, Germany, Brazil, and Indonesia [are larger](Overlap of Large Countries) than some permanent UN Security Council members (P5). Despite containing 60% of the world’s population, Asia only holds three seats (20%) on the Council. The rotating seats are divided by regions: Asia (2), Latin America (2), Africa (3), Western Europe (2), Eastern Europe (1). This setup does not reflect the current global economic power.[Proposed Reforms](Proposed Reforms) A reform proposal suggests expanding the Security Council to 21 members, adding new permanent members like Brazil, Germany, India, Indonesia, Japan, and Nigeria, increasing Asia’s presence. However, the current P5 countries, holding veto power, resist changes that might diminish their influence. Reform is possible when these countries recognize a restructured UN benefits global and their own security. The UN needs to keep pace with shifting global balances toward Asia and Africa for effective governance.

parts.title: Zheng He and the UN's Role in Modern Times
parts.body: Zheng He was a notable Chinese navigator who led many voyages to the South China Sea, Indian Ocean, and beyond during the 15th century. His expeditions exemplified China's substantial navigational and maritime capabilities. However, despite early advances, China's isolationist policy under the Ming Dynasty ultimately limited its naval expansion. The extended voyages of Zheng He represented a significant, albeit temporary, expansion in the scope of China's maritime influence. In the modern era, the United Nations (U.N.) emerged as a pivotal entity in promoting international cooperation. Established initially as an anti-fascist alliance during World War II, the U.N. focuses on sustainable development goals (SDGs), which highlight global priorities like eliminating poverty, fighting inequality, and tackling climate change. The U.N.’s goals emphasize progression towards a globally sustainable future, aligning with the sentiments of leaders and experts who emphasize the importance of shared responsibilities in addressing collective challenges.
